title: Chinese Government provides RMB 40 million grant for Takeo Temple Restoration and Conservation Project
description: On December 21, 2009, the Chinese Ministry of Commerce signed the 'Exchange of Notes on the Restoration and Conservation Project for Takeo Temple' to provide a 40 million Chinese Yuan (about US$6 million) grant for the restoration work of the deteriorating Takeo temple in the complex of Angkor Archaeological Park. The project name in Chinese is 茶胶寺保护修复工程. The Exchange of Letters was signed by Deputy Prime Minister H.E. Sok An, Cabinet Minister of the Kingdom of Cambodia and H.E. Chen Jian, Vice Minister of Commerce of the People’s Republic of China.   On 27 November 2010, the ground breaking ceremony was presided over by Cai Wu, Minister of the Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China, and Deputy Prime Minister Sok An, Minister of the Council of Ministers, as well as officials from UNESCO and Apsara Authority. The restoration was expected to take 8 years and to be completed in 2018. The maintenance project is organized and implemented by the Chinese Academy of Cultural Heritage and the International Economic Cooperation Bureau of the Ministry of Commerce of China. The Chinese Academy of Cultural Heritage undertakes the design and construction tasks. The project acceptance team is composed of 7 professionals from Zhejiang Ancient Architecture Institute.  The Temple was completed and handed over in September 2018. The certificate of giving-receiving the conservation project of Takeo Temple was signed on January 3, 2019 ("Cambodia-China Sign Eight Agreements and MoUs", "Agreements with China inked").  An official handover ceremony was held on November 10, 2022. Premier Li was accompanied by High Representative of Cambodian Prime Minister Samdech Techo Hun Sen and Deputy Prime Minister of Cambodia Chea Sophara.   The Ta Keo Temple is located in the north of Siem Reap in northwestern Cambodia, about 10 kilometers south of Siem Reap. It is part of the famous Angkor monument and is located outside the Victory Gate of Angkor Thom. The existing site of the Ta Keo Temple covers an area of ​​about 46,000 square meters, and the main building covers an area of ​​13,100 square meters.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 40 million grant for Takeo Temple Restoration and Conservation Project

# Description
On December 21, 2009, the Chinese Ministry of Commerce signed the 'Exchange of Notes on the Restoration and Conservation Project for Takeo Temple' to provide a 40 million Chinese Yuan (about US$6 million) grant for the restoration work of the deteriorating Takeo temple in the complex of Angkor Archaeological Park. The project name in Chinese is 茶胶寺保护修复工程. The Exchange of Letters was signed by Deputy Prime Minister H.E. Sok An, Cabinet Minister of the Kingdom of Cambodia and H.E. Chen Jian, Vice Minister of Commerce of the People’s Republic of China.   On 27 November 2010, the ground breaking ceremony was presided over by Cai Wu, Minister of the Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China, and Deputy Prime Minister Sok An, Minister of the Council of Ministers, as well as officials from UNESCO and Apsara Authority. The restoration was expected to take 8 years and to be completed in 2018. The maintenance project is organized and implemented by the Chinese Academy of Cultural Heritage and the International Economic Cooperation Bureau of the Ministry of Commerce of China. The Chinese Academy of Cultural Heritage undertakes the design and construction tasks. The project acceptance team is composed of 7 professionals from Zhejiang Ancient Architecture Institute.  The Temple was completed and handed over in September 2018. The certificate of giving-receiving the conservation project of Takeo Temple was signed on January 3, 2019 ("Cambodia-China Sign Eight Agreements and MoUs", "Agreements with China inked").  An official handover ceremony was held on November 10, 2022. Premier Li was accompanied by High Representative of Cambodian Prime Minister Samdech Techo Hun Sen and Deputy Prime Minister of Cambodia Chea Sophara.   The Ta Keo Temple is located in the north of Siem Reap in northwestern Cambodia, about 10 kilometers south of Siem Reap. It is part of the famous Angkor monument and is located outside the Victory Gate of Angkor Thom. The existing site of the Ta Keo Temple covers an area of ​​about 46,000 square meters, and the main building covers an area of ​​13,100 square meters.
justification: Project focuses on cultural heritage restoration without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Temple restoration and conservation project, cultural heritage focus, no energy or industrial components

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 629 million government concessional loan for National Road No. 57B (NR 57B) Rehabilitation Project
description: On December 21, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 629,091,787 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the National Road No. 57B (NR 57B) Rehabilitation Project. The borrowing terms of the GCL are as follows: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 1.25% interest rate. The proceeds from the GCL were used to finance an EPC contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC).  The purpose of the project was to rehabilitate three segments of National Road No. 57B (NR 57B) measuring 176.39 km in length: Thmor-Kol-Bavel-Sampov Loun; Baval-Phum Samseb-Phnom Prik; and Phnum Samset-Kamrieng-O Da. NR 57B is connected to National Road No. 5 (NR 5) in Battambang Province.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was supervised by Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Company.  A groundbreaking ceremony was held on March 21, 2011. The project was officially completed and the road was opened to traffic on March 10, 2014.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is  柬57B号公路修复项目.
combined_text:

# Description

The borrowing terms of the GCL are as follows: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 1.25% interest rate. The proceeds from the GCL were used to finance an EPC contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC).  The purpose of the project was to rehabilitate three segments of National Road No. 57B (NR 57B) measuring 176.39 km in length: Thmor-Kol-Bavel-Sampov Loun; Baval-Phum Samseb-Phnom Prik; and Phnum Samset-Kamrieng-O Da. NR 57B is connected to National Road No. 5 (NR 5) in Battambang Province.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was supervised by Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Company.  A groundbreaking ceremony was held on March 21, 2011. The project was officially completed and the road was opened to traffic on March 10, 2014.
justification: Road rehabilitation project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Rehabilitation of 176.39 km of National Road No. 57B, general transportation infrastructure

title: China Eximbank provides $31 million preferential buyer's credit for Kampong Trabek River Flood Control Project
description: On December 21, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed a $31,014,469 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement for the Kampong Trabek River Flood Control Project. The agreement was signed by Cambodian Secretary of State and Minister of Economy and Finance, H.E. On Poan Monirath and the Chairman of China Eximbank, Mr. Li Ruogu. The proceeds from the loan were used to partially finance an EPC contract with Guangdong Construction Engineering Construction Co., Ltd. (GDFC).  The purpose of this project was to improve flood control standards and upgrade land utilization, cultivation conditions, and grain output in Prey Veng Province. It involved the construction of a flood control dyke on both banks of Preaek Tra Beak river together with field irrigation and drainage system so as to provide an irrigation water source and ensure drainage capability.  GDFC was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project commenced on November 24, 2010 and was completed by March 21, 2015.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is Kampong Trabek河防洪项目 or 柬埔寨菠萝勉省防洪工程.2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China Eximbank provides $31 million preferential buyer's credit for Kampong Trabek River Flood Control Project

# Description
On December 21, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed a $31,014,469 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement for the Kampong Trabek River Flood Control Project. The agreement was signed by Cambodian Secretary of State and Minister of Economy and Finance, H.E. On Poan Monirath and the Chairman of China Eximbank, Mr. Li Ruogu. The proceeds from the loan were used to partially finance an EPC contract with Guangdong Construction Engineering Construction Co., Ltd. (GDFC).  The purpose of this project was to improve flood control standards and upgrade land utilization, cultivation conditions, and grain output in Prey Veng Province. It involved the construction of a flood control dyke on both banks of Preaek Tra Beak river together with field irrigation and drainage system so as to provide an irrigation water source and ensure drainage capability.  GDFC was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project commenced on November 24, 2010 and was completed by March 21, 2015.
justification: Project focuses on flood control and agricultural improvements without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Flood control dyke construction, irrigation and drainage system, focus on land utilization and grain output improvement

title: China Eximbank provides $15.2 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan for National Road 3762 (NR 3762) Rehabilitation Project
description: On December 21, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Finance signed a $15,228,192 preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement for the National Road 3762 (NR 3762) Rehabilitation Project. The borrowing terms of the loan were as follows: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, 2% interest rate. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to partially finance an EPC contract with China Road & Bridge Corporation (CRBC).  The purpose of this project was to rehabilitate a 26.45 km segment of National Road 3762 (NR 3762) that connects Senmonorom, the capital of Mondulkiri Province to Dak Dam, also in Mondulkiri Province.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation.  The project officially commenced on September 01, 2010 and was completed on December 01, 2012.  The construction period was originally expected to last 27 months.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Design-Build of National Road 3762 Rehabilitation Project. The Chinese project title is 柬埔寨3762号公路.2. The China Eximbank PBC loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.3. The loan agreement for this project was one out of 14 agreements signed by the Chinese Government and the Government of Cambodia on December 21, 2009.

# Description

The purpose of this project was to rehabilitate a 26.45 km segment of National Road 3762 (NR 3762) that connects Senmonorom, the capital of Mondulkiri Province to Dak Dam, also in Mondulkiri Province.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation.  The project officially commenced on September 01, 2010 and was completed on December 01, 2012.  The construction period was originally expected to last 27 months.
justification: Road rehabilitation project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 26.45 km road rehabilitation, general transportation infrastructure

title: China Eximbank provides $49.9 million preferential buyer's credit loan for Phase 1 of Kanghot Irrigation Development Project (Linked to Project ID#35591)
description: On October 23, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed a $49,911,971 Preferential Buyer's Credit (PBC) loan agreement for Phase 1 of the Kanghot Irrigation Development Project. The borrowing terms of the loan were as follows: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The proceeds from the PBC were used to partially finance an EPC contract with Guangdong Foreign Construction Company (GDFC). The Cambodian government also contributed $13 million to the project.  The purpose of the project was to construct an irrigation system in the Kanghot (or Kang-hot or Konghot) area within Battambang Province. It involved the construction of a river barrage and water diversion dam, water irrigation and drainage channels, and channel auxiliary buildings. Upon completion, it was expected that the project would make approximately 34.3 thousand hectares of farmland available in the Banan and Sangke districts.  GDFC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. The project commenced on November 26, 2010 and ended on June 4, 2013.  China Eximbank also provided a Government Concessional Loan (GCL) for Phase 2 of the Kanghot Irrigation Development Project (captured in linked Project ID#35591).
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 马德望省Kang-hot灌溉发展项目一期.2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.

justification: Project focuses on agricultural irrigation infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of irrigation system, river barrage, water diversion dam, and drainage channels for farmland development

title: China Eximbank provides $68.3 million preferential buyer's credit for National Road No. 62 (South Section: Kampong Thom-Tbeng Meanchey) Rehabilitation and National Road No. 8-1 and No. 8-2 Extension Project (Linked to Project ID#38785)
description: On June 26, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance signed a $68,363,120 preferential buyer's credit (PBC) agreement for the National Road No.62 (South Section: Kampong Thom-Tbeng Meanchey) Rehabilitation and National Road No. 8-1 and No. 8-2 Extension Project. The PBC carried the following borrowing terms: a 20-year maturity, a a7-year grace period, and a 2% interest rate. The proceeds of the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance an EPC (commercial) contract with Shanghai Construction Group (SCG).  The purpose of the project was to (a) rehabilitate the 128-km road (National Road No. 62 or RN 62) that connects Tbeng Meanchey, the capital of Preah Vihear Province, with Kampong Thom province's Kampong Svay district; (b) construct a 5.6km segment of Road No. 8-1 (RN 8-1) that connects Krabao in the Prey Veng province to Moeunchey in the Svay Rieng (Cambodia-Vietnam border); and (c) construct an 18.6 km segment of Road No. 8-2  (RN 8-2) that connects Anlong Chrey (Cambodia-Vietnam Border) to National Road No. 7 at Ponghea Krek.  SCG was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. The project was supervised by Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Company. According to Chinese official sources, the groundbreaking ceremony for the Rehabilitation of National Road No. 62 (South Section) was held on January 27, 2010. The road was officially inaugurated on August 8, 2012. The opening ceremony for the Extension of Roads No. 8-1 and No. 8-2 were held when National Road No. 8 was inaugurated on November 22, 2012 (see Project ID#32239).
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as Rehabilitation of Cambodia National Road No.62 (South Section: Kampong Thom-Tbeng Meanchey) & Extension Roads No. 8-1 & No. 8-2 Project. The Chinese project title is 柬埔寨62号公路南段修复项目.2. In the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020, it identifies the face value of the loan that supported this project as $15 million. AidData relies on the face value of the loan ($68,363,120) that is recorded in the Government of Cambodia’s aid and debt information management system, which is maintained on behalf of all ministries and agencies of the Royal Government of Cambodia by the Cambodian Rehabilitation and Development Board (CRDB) of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC).3. In 2008, China Eximbank provided a $57.8 million preferential buyer’s credit for the rehabilitation of the North Section of National Road No. 62 North Section (captured via Project ID#38785).
combined_text:

On June 26, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance signed a $68,363,120 preferential buyer's credit (PBC) agreement for the National Road No.62 (South Section: Kampong Thom-Tbeng Meanchey) Rehabilitation and National Road No. 8-1 and No. 8-2 Extension Project. The PBC carried the following borrowing terms: a 20-year maturity, a a7-year grace period, and a 2% interest rate. The proceeds of the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance an EPC (commercial) contract with Shanghai Construction Group (SCG). title: China Railway Group conducts feasibility study for Cambodia-Vietnam railway line
description: On 7 May 2009, Ministry of Public works And Transport of Kingdom of Cambodia and China Railway Group Limited signed a Memorandum of Understanding to conduct a feasibility study on the project. China Railway No.8 Engineering Group Co., Ltd. (CREC8) began the study in July 2009 and it was completed in 2011 at a cost of 3 million US dollars. The study found that the total cost of the proposed project to be US$686 million. The 257-km railway will start in Kampong Speu Province's Oudong District, pass by Kratie Province's Snuol District and end at Vietnam's Loc Ninh District in the southern border province of Binh Phuoc. It is estimated to take 30 months to complete.  In 2015, Minister of Public Works and Transport (Cambodia) Tram Iv Tekand was still reviewing the technical specifications and recommendations of the study by China’s railway ministry but plans to ask for support from the Chinese government to fund the project.
staff_comments: Under a scheme announced in 2008 to develop an intra-Asian railway, China purportedly offered to contribute $500 million to build the Cambodia-Vietnam stretch of the railway (Batdeng-Loc Ninh railway line). No evidence of further development for this project has been found.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Railway Group conducts feasibility study for Cambodia-Vietnam railway line

# Description
On 7 May 2009, Ministry of Public works And Transport of Kingdom of Cambodia and China Railway Group Limited signed a Memorandum of Understanding to conduct a feasibility study on the project. China Railway No.8 Engineering Group Co., Ltd. (CREC8) began the study in July 2009 and it was completed in 2011 at a cost of 3 million US dollars. The study found that the total cost of the proposed project to be US$686 million. The 257-km railway will start in Kampong Speu Province's Oudong District, pass by Kratie Province's Snuol District and end at Vietnam's Loc Ninh District in the southern border province of Binh Phuoc. It is estimated to take 30 months to complete.  In 2015, Minister of Public Works and Transport (Cambodia) Tram Iv Tekand was still reviewing the technical specifications and recommendations of the study by China’s railway ministry but plans to ask for support from the Chinese government to fund the project.
justification: Railway infrastructure project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Feasibility study for 257-km railway line, general transportation infrastructure

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 509.5 million government concessional loan for National Road No. 59 (NR 59) Rehabilitation Project
description: On December 21, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 509,593,711 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the National Road No 59 (NR 59) Rehabilitation Project. The borrowing terms of the GCL were as follows: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, 1.25% interest rate. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC contract with Shanghai Construction Group (SCG).  The purpose of this project was to rehabilitate a 144.27 km section of National Road No. 59 (NR 59) that stretches along the Cambodia-Thai Border. It runs from the National Road No.5 (NR 5) intersection in the village of Kaun Damrei (Kaun Damrey) village within Banteay Meanchey province to Battambang province and then onward to National Road No. 57 (NR 57) in Pailin province. It also passes through Kamrieng, Phnom Prik, Sampov Loun, and Malay.  SCG was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. The project was supervised by Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Company. A groundbreaking ceremony was held on February 15, 2011. The road was officially completed and opened for use on June 21, 2013.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as The Rehabilitation of National Road No. 59 Project -- Kamrieng-Phnom Prik -- Sampov Loun -- Malay -- Kaun Damrey Project.  The Chinese project title is 59号公路修复项目.
